Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Patrick Callier of Georgetown University to conduct a research project, entitled "What perceptions do listeners form from the way others speak?" during the summer of 2012 at Beijing Normal University in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Professor Diao Yanbin.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to explore how users of language unconsciously construct a picture of the people around them as they hear others speak. This project examines how hearing someone speak with a creaky-sounding voice impacts the impressions of the speaker formed by native listeners of Mandarin Chinese and asks whether these impressions are affected by other aspects of the linguistic context, such as where in a sentence the creaky voice appears.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
I engaged in research on linguistic variation in present-day Beijing Mandarin Chinese. With an interest in how people from different social backgrounds vary in the way they talk, I collected interviews with 20 Beijing residents in order to obtain a sample of speech from the area. Analysis of this data is ongoing, and is focused on how linguistic context influences whether speakers use a "creaky" voice or not. During my time collecting this data, I benefited enormously from collaboration with Chinese linguists and educators at all levels, and my sincere thanks goes out to them. Also, as part of EAPSI, I was able to discuss my research and findings with fellow scientists, many of whom came from natural science and engineering backgrounds and had little exposure to linguistic and social scientific research.

Along with my China-based advisor and collaborator, Prof. Xu Xiaoying, and her team, I also took part in a larger, long-term study of Chinese students at Beijing Normal University taking a Mandarin proficiency test, looking for sociolinguistic factors that correlate with test performance. Tentative results indicate that more proficient speakers of Mandarin used increased levels of "creaky voice" in the test environment. It is not clear at present whether creaky voice is directly related to Mandarin proficiency or if this finding is generalizable to other populations of test-takers.
